version: "3"

silent: true

tasks:
  default:
    aliases:
      - list
    desc: List all tasks
    cmd: task -l

  setup-all:
    desc: "Setup all"
    cmds:
      - task: init
      - task: brew
      - task: brew-mas
      - task: link
      - task: gui
      - task: git
      - task: other

  init:
    desc: "Install Rosetta-2 and Homebrew"
    cmd: sh ./init.sh

  brew:
    desc: "Installing apps and command line tools with Homebrew"
    cmds:
      - brew bundle --file=brewfiles/Brewfile
      # æ•°å°‘ãªã„Intel CPUã§ã‚¤ãƒ³ã‚¹ãƒˆãƒ¼ãƒ«ä¸å¯èƒ½ãªappã®ãŸã‚ã€ä¾‹å¤–çš„ã«ãƒ™ã‚¿æ›¸ã
      - if [[ $(uname -m) == "arm64" ]]; then brew install --cask chatgpt; fi

  brew-mas:
    desc: "Installing Mac App Store apps with Homebrew"
    cmd: brew bundle --file=brewfiles/Brewfile.mas

  link:
    desc: "Creating symlinks of dotfiles"
    cmd: sh ./link.sh

  gui:
    desc: "Configuring MacOS GUI"
    cmd: sh ./gui.sh

  git:
    desc: "Configuring GitHub"
    cmd: sh ./github.sh

  other:
    desc: "Configuring others"
    cmd: sh ./other.sh

#!/bin/zsh
set -e

# =============================================================================
# zplugã®ã‚¤ãƒ³ã‚¹ãƒˆãƒ¼ãƒ«ï¼ˆHomebrewçµŒç”±ã ã¨å¤‰ã«ãªã£ãŸã“ã¨ãŒã‚ã‚‹ãŸã‚å…¬å¼æ‰‹é †é€šã‚Šã«curlã§ã‚¤ãƒ³ã‚¹ãƒˆãƒ¼ãƒ«ï¼‰
# https://github.com/zplug/zplug
# =============================================================================
if [ ! -d "$HOME/.zplug" ]; then
  echo "ğŸ“¦ Installing zplug..."
  curl -sL --proto-redir -all,https https://raw.githubusercontent.com/zplug/installer/master/installer.zsh | zsh
else
  echo "âœ… zplug is already installed"
fi

# =============================================================================
# Pythonå®Ÿè¡Œç’°å¢ƒã®æ§‹ç¯‰
# =============================================================================
# miseã§æœ€æ–°ã®Pythonã‚’ã‚¤ãƒ³ã‚¹ãƒˆãƒ¼ãƒ«ï¼†ã‚°ãƒ­ãƒ¼ãƒãƒ«ãªãƒãƒ¼ã‚¸ãƒ§ãƒ³ã«è¨­å®š
echo "ğŸ“¦ Installing Python with mise..."
mise use -g python@latest

# =============================================================================
# Node.jså®Ÿè¡Œç’°å¢ƒã®æ§‹ç¯‰
# =============================================================================
# miseã§æœ€æ–°ã®Node.jsã‚’ã‚¤ãƒ³ã‚¹ãƒˆãƒ¼ãƒ«ï¼†ã‚°ãƒ­ãƒ¼ãƒãƒ«ãªãƒãƒ¼ã‚¸ãƒ§ãƒ³ã«è¨­å®š
echo "ğŸ“¦ Installing Node.js with mise..."
mise use -g node@latest

# Node.jsã®ã‚¤ãƒ³ã‚¹ãƒˆãƒ¼ãƒ«ã‚’å¾…æ©Ÿã—ã¦ã‹ã‚‰ npm ãƒ‘ãƒƒã‚±ãƒ¼ã‚¸ã‚’ã‚¤ãƒ³ã‚¹ãƒˆãƒ¼ãƒ«
echo "ğŸ“¦ Installing global npm packages..."
npm i -g @dataform/cli

content.content:
# Entire CLI

Entire hooks into your git workflow to capture AI agent sessions on every push. Sessions are indexed alongside commits, creating a searchable record of how code was written in your repo.

With Entire, you can:

* **Understand why code changed** â€” see the full prompt/response transcript and files touched
* **Recover instantly** â€” rewind to a known-good checkpoint when an agent goes sideways and resume seamlessly
* **Keep Git history clean** â€” preserve agent context on a separate branch
* **Onboard faster** â€” show the path from prompt â†’ change â†’ commit
* **Maintain traceability** â€” support audit and compliance requirements when needed

## Table of Contents

- [Quick Start](#quick-start)
- [Typical Workflow](#typical-workflow)
- [Key Concepts](#key-concepts)
  - [How It Works](#how-it-works)
  - [Strategies](#strategies)
- [Commands Reference](#commands-reference)
- [Configuration](#configuration)
- [Troubleshooting](#troubleshooting)
- [Development](#development)
- [Getting Help](#getting-help)
- [License](#license)

## Requirements

- Git
- macOS or Linux (Windows via WSL)
- [Claude Code](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code) or [Gemini CLI](https://github.com/google-gemini/gemini-cli) installed and authenticated

## Quick Start

```bash
# Install via Homebrew
brew tap entireio/tap
brew install entireio/tap/entire

# Or install via Go
go install github.com/entireio/cli/cmd/entire@latest

# Enable in your project
cd your-project && entire enable

# Check status
entire status
```

## Typical Workflow

### 1. Enable Entire in Your Repository

```
entire enable
```

This installs agent and git hooks to work with your AI agent (Claude Code or Gemini CLI). The hooks capture session data at specific points in your workflow. Your code commits stay cleanâ€”all session metadata is stored on a separate `entire/checkpoints/v1` branch.

**When checkpoints are created** depends on your chosen strategy (default is `manual-commit`):
- **Manual-commit**: Checkpoints are created when you or the agent make a git commit
- **Auto-commit**: Checkpoints are created after each agent response

### 2. Work with Your AI Agent

Just use Claude Code or Gemini CLI normally. Entire runs in the background, tracking your session:

```
entire status  # Check current session status anytime
```

### 3. Rewind to a Previous Checkpoint

If you want to undo some changes and go back to an earlier checkpoint:

```
entire rewind
```

This shows all available checkpoints in the current session. Select one to restore your code to that exact state.

### 4. Resume a Previous Session

To restore the latest checkpointed session metadata for a branch:

```
entire resume <branch>
```

Entire checks out the branch, restores the latest checkpointed session metadata (one or more sessions), and prints command(s) to continue.

### 5. Disable Entire (Optional)

```
entire disable
```

Removes the git hooks. Your code and commit history remain untouched.

## Key Concepts

- [Troubleshooting](#troubleshooting)
- [Development](#development)
- [Getting Help](#getting-help)
- [License](#license)

## Requirements

- Git
- macOS or Linux (Windows via WSL)
- [Claude Code](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code) or [Gemini CLI](https://github.com/google-gemini/gemini-cli) installed and authenticated

## Quick Start

```bash
# Install via Homebrew
brew tap entireio/tap
brew install entireio/tap/entire

# Or install via Go
go install github.com/entireio/cli/cmd/entire@latest

# Enable in your project
cd your-project && entire enable

# Check status
entire status
```

## Typical Workflow

### 1. Enable Entire in Your Repository

```
entire enable
```

This installs agent and git hooks to work with your AI agent (Claude Code or Gemini CLI). The hooks capture session data at specific points in your workflow. Your code commits stay cleanâ€”all session metadata is stored on a separate `entire/checkpoints/v1` branch.

**When checkpoints are created** depends on your chosen strategy (default is `manual-commit`):
- **Manual-commit**: Checkpoints are created when you or the agent make a git commit
- **Auto-commit**: Checkpoints are created after each agent response

### 2. Work with Your AI Agent

Just use Claude Code or Gemini CLI normally. Entire runs in the background, tracking your session:

```
entire status  # Check current session status anytime
```

### 3. Rewind to a Previous Checkpoint

If you want to undo some changes and go back to an earlier checkpoint:

```
entire rewind
```

This shows all available checkpoints in the current session. Select one to restore your code to that exact state.

### 4. Resume a Previous Session

To restore the latest checkpointed session metadata for a branch:

```
entire resume <branch>
```

Entire checks out the branch, restores the latest checkpointed session metadata (one or more sessions), and prints command(s) to continue.

### 5. Disable Entire (Optional)

```
entire disable
```

Removes the git hooks. Your code and commit history remain untouched.

## Key Concepts

export CLICOLOR=1
autoload -Uz compinit && compinit

# PATHã‚’é€šã™
export PATH="$PATH:/usr/local/sbin"
export PATH="$PATH:/usr/local/bin"
export PATH="$PATH:/opt/homebrew/bin" # Homebrew (ARM)
export PATH="$PATH:$HOME/.local/bin"  # pipx
export PATH="$PATH:$HOME/.rd/bin"     # Rancher Desktop

# Claude Codeã®ã‚¨ãƒ©ãƒ¼è§£æ¶ˆç”¨
export TMPDIR="$HOME/.tmp"

# Initialization
# ============================================================
# zplug
source "$HOME/.zplug/init.zsh"

# mise
eval "$(mise activate zsh)"

# Zoxide
eval "$(zoxide init zsh)"

# google-cloud-sdk
source "$(brew --prefix)/share/google-cloud-sdk/path.zsh.inc"
source "$(brew --prefix)/share/google-cloud-sdk/completion.zsh.inc"
# ============================================================

# Alias
# ============================================================
## Substitution of basic commands
alias cd='z'
alias ls='lsd -F --group-directories-first'
alias find='fd'
alias cat='bat'
alias grep='rg'
# alias curl='https' # â† ã•ã™ãŒã« curl ã¨ã¯é•ã„ã™ããŸ
alias ps='procs'
alias top='btm'
alias df='duf'
alias du='dust'

## General
alias vi='vim'
alias ll='ls -lg'
alias la='ls -A'
alias sz='source ~/.zshrc'
alias cz='cat ~/.zshrc'
alias vz='vi ~/.zshrc'
alias rm='trash' # https://github.com/andreafrancia/trash-cli

## Git
alias g='git'
compdef g=git

alias gs='git status'
alias ga='git add'
alias gc='git commit'
alias gl='git log'
alias gd='git diff'
alias gsw='git switch -C'
alias gcm='git switch main'
alias gsl='git stash list'

## gcloud
alias gcloud-switch='switch_gcloud_configuration'

function switch_gcloud_configuration() {
  gcloud config configurations activate $(gcloud config configurations list | awk '{print $1}' | grep -v NAME | peco)
}
# ============================================================

# Zplug plugins
zplug "yous/lime"
zplug "zsh-users/zsh-completions"
# zplug "zsh-users/zsh-autosuggestions"
zplug "zsh-users/zsh-history-substring-search"
zplug "zsh-users/zsh-syntax-highlighting"
zplug "greymd/docker-zsh-completion"

# 'cd' ãªã—ã§ç§»å‹•ã™ã‚‹
setopt auto_cd
setopt auto_pushd

# é‡è¤‡ã™ã‚‹ãƒ‡ã‚£ãƒ¬ã‚¯ãƒˆãƒªã¯è¨˜éŒ²ã—ãªã„ã‚ˆã†ã«ã™ã‚‹
setopt correct

# 'cd -' [Tab] ã§ä»¥å‰ç§»å‹•ã—ãŸãƒ‡ã‚£ãƒ¬ã‚¯ãƒˆãƒªã«ç§»å‹•ã™ã‚‹

# ç§»å‹•ã—ãŸå¾Œã¯ 'ls' ã™ã‚‹

## Situation

  - `curl`

## Usage
ã‚¹ã‚¿ãƒ¼ãƒˆã¯ã©ã“ã®ãƒ‡ã‚£ãƒ¬ã‚¯ãƒˆãƒªã§ã‚‚åˆ¥ã«ã„ã„ã‘ã©ã€ãƒ›ãƒ¼ãƒ ãƒ‡ã‚£ãƒ¬ã‚¯ãƒˆãƒªä¸Šã§ã‚„ã‚‹ã®ãŒå¥½ã¾ã—ã„ã‹ã‚‚

```bash
$ git clone https://github.com/snhryt-neo/dotfiles.git
$ cd dotfiles
$ sh -c "$(curl --location https://taskfile.dev/install.sh)" -- -d # ã‚¿ã‚¹ã‚¯ãƒ©ãƒ³ãƒŠãƒ¼ã® go-task ã‚’ãƒã‚¤ãƒŠãƒªã‹ã‚‰ã‚¤ãƒ³ã‚¹ãƒˆãƒ¼ãƒ«
$ export PATH="$PATH:$(pwd)/bin"      # go-task ãŒ ./bin ã«ã‚¤ãƒ³ã‚¹ãƒˆãƒ¼ãƒ«ã•ã‚Œã‚‹ã®ã§ãƒ‘ã‚¹ã‚’é€šã™
$ export GIT_USER_EMAIL="xxxxx@xxxxx" # GitHubã«ç™»éŒ²ã—ã¦ã„ã‚‹ãƒ¡ãƒ¼ãƒ«ã‚¢ãƒ‰ãƒ¬ã‚¹
$ task setup-all
# ä»¥é™ã€å¤§ä½“20åˆ†ãã‚‰ã„ã‹ã‹ã‚‹ï¼†ã¡ã‚‡ã“ã¡ã‚‡ã“ã‚¤ãƒ³ã‚¿ãƒ©ã‚¯ãƒ†ã‚£ãƒ–ã«ã‚¿ãƒ¼ãƒŸãƒŠãƒ«æ“ä½œã™ã‚‹å¿…è¦ã‚ã‚Š
# ã‚¨ãƒ©ãƒ¼ãŒç™ºç”Ÿã—ãŸã‚‰ task other ã®ã‚ˆã†ã«ã‚¿ã‚¹ã‚¯å€‹åˆ¥ã§æŒ‡å®šã™ã‚‹ã¨åŠ¹ç‡ã‚ˆã—
$ rm -r ./bin # HomebrewçµŒç”±ã§ go-task ã‚¤ãƒ³ã‚¹ãƒˆãƒ¼ãƒ«æ¸ˆã®ãŸã‚ã€ãƒã‚¤ãƒŠãƒªã‹ã‚‰ã‚¤ãƒ³ã‚¹ãƒˆãƒ¼ãƒ«ã—ãŸã‚‚ã®ã¯æ¶ˆã™
```

I've completed the web search for your query about Claude Code, CLAUDE.md configuration placement, and the .claude directory.

Here are the key findings from the search results:

## CLAUDE.md Configuration Locations

CLAUDE.md can be placed in three different locations: as a project memory in the project root directory (./CLAUDE.md), as user memory in the home directory (~/.claude/CLAUDE.md) which applies to all projects, and as local project memory (./CLAUDE.local.md), though this is currently deprecated.

## .claude Directory Usage

When Claude Code is started, a hidden .claude directory is automatically created in the user's home directory, which contains important files supporting Claude Code's operation, including .credentials.json for API authentication, projects/ for session history, shell-snapshots/, statsig/, and todos/ directories.

Custom commands intended for use across all projects should be placed in the ~/.claude/commands directory.

## Hierarchical Configuration

Claude Code automatically searches for CLAUDE.md files not only in the project root but also in parent and subdirectories, allowing for configurations like repository root for shared rules and each package subdirectory for service-specific rules.

A configuration structure can include .claude/ with main project settings and rules/ subdirectory containing modular rules for code style, testing, and security.

The search results contain information current as of early 2026, including recent articles about Claude Code best practices and configuration management.

I found comprehensive information about Claude Code project configuration and CLAUDE.md best practices. Here are the key findings:

## What is CLAUDE.md?

CLAUDE.md is a special file that Claude reads at the start of every conversation. It acts as a configuration file that Claude automatically incorporates into every conversation, ensuring it always knows your project structure, coding standards, and preferred workflows.

## Getting Started

Run /init to generate a starter CLAUDE.md file based on your current project structure, then refine over time. The /init command serves as a starting point, not a finished product. The generated CLAUDE.md captures obvious patterns but may miss nuances specific to your workflow. Review what Claude produces and refine it based on your team's actual practices.

## What to Include

Include Bash commands, code style, and workflow rules. This gives Claude persistent context it can't infer from code alone. Key sections should cover:

- Common bash commands: npm run test, npm run build, etc.
- Code style guidelines: "Use ES modules, not CommonJS," or "Always use functional components with hooks."
- Key files or architectural patterns: "State management is handled by Zustand; see src/stores for examples." Testing instructions: "New components require a corresponding test file using React Testing Library."

## Best Practices

1. **Keep it concise**: There's no required format for CLAUDE.md files, but keep it short and human-readable.

2. **Prioritize quality over quantity**: Your CLAUDE.md file should contain as few instructions as possible - ideally only ones which are universally applicable to your task.

3. **Reflect actual practices**: The most effective CLAUDE.md files solve real problems: they document the commands you type repeatedly, capture the architectural context that takes ten minutes to explain, and establish workflows that prevent rework. Your file should reflect how your team actually develops softwareâ€”not theoretical best practices that sound good but don't match reality.

4. **Maintain continuously**: Treat customization as an ongoing practice rather than a one-time setup task. A well-maintained CLAUDE.md evolves with your codebase, continuously reducing the friction of working with AI assistance on complex software.

Web search results for query: "Claude Code .claude directory structure commands configuration"

Links: [{"title":"Claude Code settings - Claude Code Docs","url":"https://code.claude.com/docs/en/settings"},{"title":"Shipyard | Claude Code CLI Cheatsheet: config, commands, prompts, + best practices","url":"https://shipyard.build/blog/claude-code-cheat-sheet/"},{"title":"Understand configuration directories in Claude Code - M.academy","url":"https://m.academy/lessons/understand-configuration-directories-claude-code/"},{"title":"Claude Code Configuration Guide | ClaudeLog","url":"https://claudelog.com/configuration/"},{"title":"The .claude Folder: A 10-Minute Setup That Makes AI Code Smarter | by Manojkumar Vadivel | Medium","url":"https://medium.com/@manojkumar.vadivel/the-claude-folder-a-10-minute-setup-that-makes-ai-code-smarter-93da465ef39e"},{"title":"GitHub - ChrisWiles/claude-code-showcase: Comprehensive Claude Code project configuration example with hooks, skills, agents, commands, and GitHub Actions workflows","url":"https://github.com/ChrisWiles/claude-code-showcase"},{"title":"The .claude folder","url":"https://buildermethods.com/library/claude-md"},{"title":"How I use Claude Code (+ my best tips)","url":"https://www.builder.io/blog/claude-code"},{"title":"GitHub - feiskyer/claude-code-settings: Claude Code settings, commands and agents for vibe coding","url":"https://github.com/feiskyer/claude-code-settings"},{"title":"Feature Request: Configure Additional Directories via Settings Files Â· Issue #3146 Â· anthropics/claude-code","url":"https://github.com/anthropics/claude-code/issues/3146"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about Claude Code's `.claude` directory structure, commands, and configuration:

## .claude Directory Structure

Claude Code uses global and project-specific hidden .claude directories to manage configuration, history, and custom tools, enabling flexible workspace and team collaboration.

A typical project-level `.claude` directory structure looks like this:


```
.claude/
â”œâ”€ rules.md # coding standards and guardrails
â”œâ”€ context.md # what this project is and how it runs
â”œâ”€ prompts.md # reusable prompt snippets for common tasks
â””â”€ settings.json # optional structured preferences
```


The .claude folder houses your settings.json, custom commands, skills, and subagent configurations. Understanding the difference between project-level and system-level folders is key â€” anything placed in your home directory's .claude folder becomes available across all your projects.

## Key Configuration Files

### CLAUDE.md (Memory Files)
CLAUDE.md is Claude's persistent memory that loads automatically at session start. You can place it at .claude/CLAUDE.md (project, in .claude folder), ./CLAUDE.md (project root), or ~/.claude/CLAUDE.md (user-level, all projects). Include: Project stack and architecture overview, key commands (test, build, lint, deploy), code style guidelines, important directories and their purposes, and critical rules and constraints.

### settings.json (Main Configuration)
The main configuration file for hooks, environment variables, and permissions. MCP configuration can be stored in multiple locations: Project-scoped MCP (.mcp.json in your project directory), project-specific (.claude/settings.local.json in your project directory), or user-specific local (~/.claude/settings.local.json).

### Custom Commands
To add commands, just create a .claude/commands folder, add the command name as a file with a .md extension. You just write these in natural language and you can use the $ARGUMENTS string to place arguments into the prompt.

### Skills
Skills are markdown-based guides that teach Claude Code how to handle specific tasks. Unlike slash commands, skills are invoked via natural language, so Claude decides when to use them.

## Configuration and Commands

### /config Command
You can configure Claude Code by running the /config command when using the interactive REPL, which opens a tabbed Settings interface where you can view status information and modify configuration options.

### /help Command
The /help command shows all available slash commands, including your custom commands from .claude/commands/ and ~/.claude/commands/ directories, as well as any commands you have from connected MCP servers.

### Multi-Directory Setup
Claude Code can access multiple directories beyond your current working directory using CLI argument --add-dir (added in v1.0.18) when starting Claude Code or slash command /add-dir mid-session for seamless workflow expansion.

### Permissions Configuration
Permissions can be configured with allowed tools and deny rules in settings.json, specifying which operations and file paths are permitted or blocked. Most devs approve actions individually.

Settings files (JSON) can configure permissions, environment variables, and tool behavior, with precedence: Higher-level configurations (Managed) override lower-level ones (User/Project) and inheritance where settings are merged, with more specific settings adding to or overriding broader ones.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Based on the search results, here are the best practices for Claude Code CLAUDE.md and .claude directory placement as of 2026:

## File Placement

CLAUDE.md can be placed at the project root (./CLAUDE.md) to be shared with your team via git, or named CLAUDE.md.local and .gitignored for personal use. It can also be placed in parent directories for monorepo setups, or in child directories where Claude will pull them on demand when working with files in those directories. The repository root is the recommended location, or wherever you run claude, with additional CLAUDE.md files in sub-directories for local rules if needed.

Claude Code reads information from CLAUDE.md files in a hierarchical order: first from your home directory (~/.claude/CLAUDE.md), then from your project root, and finally from individual directories.

## Directory Structure for Larger Projects

For larger projects, you can use a .claude/rules/ directory structure where all markdown files in .claude/rules/ are automatically loaded with the same priority as your main CLAUDE.md. You can also create SKILL.md files in .claude/skills/ to give Claude domain knowledge and reusable workflows, which Claude applies automatically when relevant, or you can invoke them directly with /skill-name.

## Best Practices for Content

CLAUDE.md is loaded every session, so only include things that apply broadly. For domain knowledge or workflows that are only relevant sometimes, use skills instead as Claude loads them on demand without bloating every conversation. CLAUDE.md should not exceed 150+ lines.

Keep it concise. For each line, ask: "Would removing this cause Claude to make mistakes?" If not, cut it.

Now I have more information. The key points are:

1. **CLAUDE.md placement**: It can be at the project root (./CLAUDE.md) which is the most common, or at ~/.claude/CLAUDE.md for global settings, or in subdirectories. The root is recommended.

2. **`.claude/rules/` directory**: For larger projects, you can use `.claude/rules/` directory where all markdown files are automatically loaded with the same priority as your main CLAUDE.md.

3. **CLAUDE.md is correctly placed at the root**. It doesn't need to go inside `.claude/`.

So the current CLAUDE.md at the repo root is actually the correct and recommended placement. 

The user was asking in Japanese whether the root directory is the right place for CLAUDE.md, and whether `.claude/` might be better instead. The answer is clear: the root is the correct location, and `.claude/` is not the right place for the main CLAUDE.md file. I'm confirming that keeping CLAUDE.md at the repository root is the right approachâ€”it's the standard best practice. The `.claude/` directory is meant for configuration files like settings.json and local overrides, not for the rules file itself.

The user says the CI is failing because "No available formula with the name 'entireio/tap/entire'". Let me check the Brewfile and look at how entire is installed via brew.

From the earlier research, the README said:
```bash
brew tap entireio/tap
brew install entireio/tap/entire
```

But when we installed it earlier, the output showed:
```
==> Installing Cask entire
```

So it seems like `entire` is a **cask**, not a formula! I installed it as a cask earlier. The Brewfile currently has:
```
brew "entireio/tap/entire"
```

But it should be:


```
cask "entireio/tap/entire"
```

Let me verify this is the right fix by checking the Brewfile again.
